messages.text: Train

<!channel>:  Hey, JavaScripters! This is a call for help! I want to do a short 15 minute demo about debugging client-side JavaScript with the Chrome Developer tools at the next Hack + Help, and I was wondering if anybody wanted to help me. Anything would be great, it would be cool to tag-team a demo. 

Most of all, I'm all a-flutter about breaking on exceptions and XHR requests. Does anybody have any code snippets that explore exceptions or AJAX? Let me know!!

Oh, and if you'd like to do a short interactive lightening talk at Hack + Help that isn't about this topic, please pick one that you'd rather do. Even if it's just ten minutes on some topic, it would be great!
q
To set up your psql to be more readable  ```$ subl ~/.psqlrc ``` and add \x auto to that file and save.
don't feel like you have to respond right now that would be crazy
for somereason I needed to install sqlite3 anyone else have this problem?
thanks <@U02J974JP> !!!
I forgot ./node_modules/.bin/knex init after installing pg
<!channel> anyone going to the javascript admirers' meetup tonight at 7pm?

Make Directory

Yo Caribou
Select all the options

Git Init stuff 

npm install --save admit-one admit-one-bookshelf
npm install --save knex bookshelf bluebird
 npm install pg


Add usage code from the admit-one book shelf to knex.js
Make a database in psql
Migrate to database
Add migration info from the admit one bookshelf to the migration file.
bower i --save admit-one-ember
add “app/bower_components/admit-one-ember/dist/adm” to the package.json file
Add Usage info from the Admit one main page to the sever
Add Usage info from the Admit one ember page to the app
Add templates
Be sure to change mongo stuff
We don’t need versions for api’s

```
	"todoreview":
	{
		"exclude_folders":
		[
			"tmp",
			"out",
			"*/.*",
			"*/coverage/*",
			"*/node_modules/*",
			"*/bower_components/*"
		]
	}
```

The article highlights home computers being marketed to boys and the resulting experience boys had before coming to university. That's bad enough. But there are also some quotes from professors who seemed to be actively dismissive of people who were there to learn. I think the universities carry a lot of the blame and that behavior continues to this day.

attachments.title: When Women Stopped Coding
attachments.text: For decades, the share of women majoring in computer science was rising. Then, in the 1980s, something changed.

file.preview:
sudo httpd -k start -C "User `whoami`" -C "Listen 8000" -X -d . -f httpd.conf

# `killall -9 httpd` if required to stop the server

messages.text: <@U02HU6FTQ|wbyoung> shared a file: <https://portlandcodeschool.slack.com/files/wbyoung/F02PJ0JMW/httpd_conf.txt|httpd.conf>

file.name: httpd_conf.txt
file.title: httpd.conf
file.preview:
DocumentRoot "."
ServerName localhost
ErrorLog "apache_error_log"
LogLevel warn

LoadModule authz_host_module /usr/libexec/apache2/mod_authz_host.so
LoadModule auth_basic_module /usr/libexec/apache2/mod_auth_basic.so
LoadModule auth_digest_module /usr/libexec/apache2/mod_auth_digest.so
LoadModule deflate_module /usr/libexec/apache2/mod_deflate.so
LoadModule log_config_module /usr/libexec/apache2/mod_log_config.so
file.preview_highlight:

This won't get your theme operational, though. You'll probably have to learn how theme development in WordPress works. It's likely that you have to have a working WP site locally and then add the theme before you can tweak it.

It's a promise thing.

node? bookself?

That's the gist of it.
That makes sense. Don't write tests that depend on other things working
Good job keeping everyone on task, <@U02J971SX>.
Feel free to continue working on the backend over the weekend if you want or trying to add a front-end to this as well.
Chat for a bit if you want. Jot down any questions that you'd like to discuss in more detail Monday, but I'd call that a day!
You guys did great today!
I sent one last PR that does a bunch of promise related stuff. You don't need to accept that one.
It should have a full explanation, but the short of it is that there's no reason that we _have_ to use a `POST` request in order to test the `GET` request. Therefore, we shouldn't.
Then also look at the PR that I just sent over.
right, that makes a lot of sense
And I just sent a PR for the test update.
I mentioned this once before, but some JSON libraries don't do the best job with anything other than an object as the root object.
so obvious
derp
And I changed the `res.json` that you're sending back to be an object containing an array.
I made 2 changes. I returned the test to the original expectation.
that equaled the array
it wasn't returning an object with a "doctors" property
Yup, pull down the latest.
but for realz, we were parsing the body object and getting back an array with one item in it
:smoking:
:smile_cat:
not really
joking...
I don't know if you're serious or not.
beer cam out
steve forced everyone to drink
we are all wasted
I'll push real quick something that makes that work.
You should not have changed the expectation, though.
It looks great!
Checking…
will you check our passing test now
Type `q` to get out of the `less` program.
If you `git log` you should see _Test failing for the right reason._ as the first log message.
I pushed something that you should pull (a few minutes ago).
oh kewl
And all the callbacky stuff is good.
Yes, it's a good idea.
all callbacky and stuff?
so our test idea was appropriate: that we needed to do a post request, then do a get request for that data?
hold up
Your test file should be perfect at this point.
